Posts.Title: To eat or not to eat some things...

Posts.Content: I am not suggesting or advising anything, just telling you my situation. I am currently 69 years of age. Four years ago this month, I had a biopsy based on a 4.2 PSA and family history (brother, PCa). Result from 12 cores was two cores 5%, 3+3, went on AS. PSA every six months since then has never been higher than 3.3, once actually 1.9. My URO has been in no hurry to do a biopsy in these four years but did suggest that having one this year would be prudent. I have my next PSA in two weeks and frankly, if it is below 3, I am not sure I will have the biopsy. But that's just me, a guy with a very low volume, 3+3 diagnosis and a declining PSA. As always, decisions any individual makes should be in concert with your doctor.

AgeInfo.Phrase: <Z> <Z> I am currently 69 years of age <Z> <Z>

Posts.Title: Nothing found on second biopsy.....now what?

AgeInfo.Phrase: <Z> <Z> I am currently 69 years of age <Z> <Z>

Posts.Title: Nothing found on second biopsy.....now what?

Posts.Content: Yes, of course, anything can change at any time. A meteor could fall out of the sky and knock your head off. Do you spend a lot of time worrying about that? I think the way we play the cards we are dealt is less about the psychology of pca and more about the psychology of us, as individuals. I have a similar diagnosis to yours, four years now. I have explicit trust in my doctor and continue on AS. My PSA has never been higher than the 4.2 that triggered the biopsy (along with family history--brother) in 2015. Most recently, last month, it was 2.5. I really don't think much about cancer. I live in a pleasant climate, I am fit and healthy, I have wonderful grandchildren that make me smile and laugh. I know that hearing the word "cancer" is frightening. But as we hear over and over on this forum, prostate cancer when caught early is very treatable, even curable. I had a neighbor who had radical prostatectomy when he was 51. He died last fall at the age of 81 from heart disease. It really sounds like your doctor and you are ahead of the curve on your situation. That is a good thing. If the meteor is coming at you, you will see it well in advance. Yes, get outside and exercise. And then, do it some more.

AgeInfo.Phrase: fall at the age of 81 from heart disease <Z> <Z>

Posts.Title: The psychology of pca

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by IceStationZebra Funny you should mention a meteor, I’ve often said that if I had my choice of how to go, getting dead centered by a meteor would be quick, painless and newsworthy! �� I don’t think it’s as simple as you State. You’re coming at it from a different perspective and clarity, having the benefit of time with it. This is a month old for me, not quite that (although I’ve been in the testing loop for a year). Unfortunately, we don’t go through this in a vacuum. I think if I could get everything else to stop falling apart of once, I’d be in decent shape. I’m managing this pca and several life adjustments all at the same time. It’s hard not to feel like you’re being hit with a tsunami at times. So we have exercise and life distractions (grandkids). I don’t want any grandkids right now though, my kids are 20 and 16! Sorry, I guess I misunderstood when you said, "Maybe we can all pitch in ideas about how we cope with this mess we find ourselves in". I thought you were looking for ideas, not sympathy. In my opinion, it is as simple as I state. I can use my mind to either make things better or make things worse. It's up to me. I have been a member of this forum for four years and have posted 20 times. You have been a member for one year and have posted 285 times. Maybe you need to give yourself a break. Look, no one can tell you what is going to happen five years from now but the fact is that you currently have a very low level cancer and you are on top of it. Are you aware that there is even discussion among urologists and pathologists as to whether Gleason 3+3 should even be classified as cancer? This is just me pitching in ideas, but I really think your glass is half full, man.

Posts.Title: The psychology of pca

Posts.Content: I am 69 years old, diagnosed a little over three years ago. Uro did biopsy because of a 4.2 PSA and family history. 12 cores, 2 with 5% funky, Gleason 6. I have been on AS and feeling very comfortable with it. Six month PSA checks have been in the 2's, with one actually 1.9, nothing even close to 4.2 of three years ago. I go back in September for next PSA six month check. So my question is this--Even with my numbers and feeling pretty comfortable, does there a come a time where a biopsy is done again, just as an additional "to be sure" check? Thanks for any thoughts.

AgeInfo.Phrase: <Z> AS question I am 69 years old  diagnosed a little

Posts.Title: AS question

Posts.Content: Two years ago (March, 2015) I had a PSA of 4.2 at age 65. Have a brother with PCa so my urologist did a biopsy. Twelve cores, ten clean, two 5% invlovement, Gleason 6. His advice was active surveillance which I had no problem agreeing to. Six months later my PSA had dropped to mid 3's; six months later, low 3's; six months later, high 2's; last week, 2.3. Will do it again in six months one month after my 68th birthday. My doctor, who I trust explicitly, remains very comfortable with active surveillance, as do I. I look at this forum often enough to know that many people have very serious cases that need to be dealt with aggressively. There are, however, cases like mine where active surveillance seems totally appropriate. My doctor says that he has seen hundreds of cancers like mine and has never known one to metastasize. I understand that when it comes to cells in our bodies, crazy things can happen at any given moment, so I am not forgetting that I have this diagnosis. PSA checks every six months will be my routine. This post is not designed to give anyone here any advice. It is just my current story.
Posts.Title: My story, currently.

Posts.Content: Thoughts, yes. Suggestions, not really. I am 69 years of age and other than my PCa diagnosis (which causes me no symptoms or pain) I am pretty healthy and have always been. My BMI is 22, cholesterol is good, blood pressure stays below 120/80. I walk five miles a day and eat well most of the time. Curiously though, I have been bugged by mild but noticeable headaches in my left temple for about twenty years. It is not all the time, maybe four or five times a year, and they usually hang around for 2-3 weeks. When they are here they are very distracting and I find it hard to concentrate. Sometimes I lay down and take a nap simply because I want to get away from them. When I was still working I attributed them to stress and my GP was on board with that. I have been retired now for over ten years, have basically no stress in my life, but the headaches always return. And they always go away. Right or wrong, I have come to believe that there is no physical cause for these headaches and I have made peace with that. I guess I would ask, have you had a complete blood count?

AgeInfo.Phrase: <Z> <Z> <Z> I am 69 years of age and other

Posts.Title: Help requested.

Posts.Content: Thank you, Chuck & Otago; your thoughts and info are very helpful. Yes Chuck, the March PSA could have been affected by a couple of the things you mentioned. The July PSA, no. So, that makes sense. Otago, my brother is 2 years older than me and was diagnosed when he was 62, five years ago. I don't know any of the numbers associated with his pc but do know that he had seeds and radiation. We don't talk much but when we do he says things are good, PSA not going crazy. I have been having PSA's for the last 6 or 7 years. I don't have year by year but they were always around 2 until March, 2014, when it was 3.1. Doctor wasn't alarmed at the time, then came the 4.2 this past March that triggered the biopsy. And then, of course, came the 3.1 this month. I am not freaked out by this diagnosis and am sleeping soundly every night, as you suggest, Otago. I have read professional articles where it is suggested that Gleason 6 should not even be classified as cancer. My plan is to stick with AS for the next year, have another biopsy, and then probably put this thing on the back burner.

AgeInfo.Phrase: was diagnosed when he was 62  five years ago <Z> <Z>

Posts.Title: Prostate cancer and dropping PSA?

Posts.Content: 65 years of age, PSA was 4.2 in March, doctor did biopsy; I also have a brother with pc. 12 cores, 2 were 5%, Gleason 6. Doctor recommended active surveillance. PSA in July, four months later, was 3.1. I was surprised by this, expecting it to be the same or higher, but not lower. He gave an explanation that I didn't totally understand. Anyone have experience with this occurrence, or knowledge of it? Thank you. (BTW, I like my doctor a lot; he is excellent).
Posts.Title: Prostate cancer and dropping PSA?

Posts.Content: I understand that every person's biology is not exactly the same, nor is everyone's cancer. While no one should make any diagnostic or treatment decisions based on what they read here, I do believe that some 3+3, low core volume pca can regress. Or, if not regress, not get any worse.
Posts.Title: New MRI Results - MY PCa is Regressing

Posts.Content: I understand that every person's biology is not exactly the same, nor is everyone's cancer. While no one should make any diagnostic or treatment decisions based on what they read here, I do believe that some 3+3, low core volume pca can regress. Or, if not regress, not get any worse.
Posts.Title: New MRI Results - MY PCa is Regressing

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by motoman1 Yes, my first one Ive ever had. Had second one at the urologist. Still awaiting results on that one. Thanks andy12, I do tend to get ahead of myself, just worried as this PSA number seems so high compared to others I have seen and I assume the worst. Doesnt statistically say at this high number generally points towards a higher cancer risk? Well yes, it is high, which is exactly why I would want confirmation. Results of your second check will just take a few days so you won't have to wait very long. Statistically yes, lower PSA is better news than higher. Your urologist is undoubtedly the best one to have that conversation with.

Posts.Content: On the rare occasion when I find myself fearful, I think of the absolutely wonderful life I have had. None of us get out of here alive. It is that knowledge that inspires me to cherish every day I am here, to cherish the people I love and who love me.
